EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving storm system produced 6 to 12 inches of heavy wet snow across parts of Northeast Kansas. Very little in the way of snowfall accumulation occurred south of this line since air temperatures were in the lower to middle 30s and the significant accumulation occurred in areas of heavy precipitation while other areas that received snow saw it melt as it fell.  Damage estimates of 1.6 million dollars included damage to power poles across Washington, Marshall, Republic and Cloud counties with the worst damage across Washington and Marshall Counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low pressure system brought a heavy wet snow to far southeast Nebraska.  The precipitation started as rain...mixed with then changed to snow before sunrise on the 16th and then mixed back with rain or changed over to rain later that afternoon.  However, before it did visibilities dropped to a 1/4 mile or less and snowfall rates of around 2 inches an hour were briefly reached.  Total snowfall of 6 to 10 inches was common along and to about 25 miles north of the Kansas border.  Higher amounts included 10 inches in Endicott and 8 inches at Diller and 5 miles northeast of Falls City.  The heavy wet snow caused numerous accidents and the weight of the snow downed tree branches onto power lines causing power losses to around 6,200 customers.  Schools were canceled or let out early on the 16th and several were still closed on the 17th.  Nebraska Emergency Management estimated that the storm caused more than $3.5 million in damages and a federal disaster declaration was approved for the counties involved in the storm.

The storms produced winds of 125 mph across the eastern Aleutians and Alaska Peninsula and to 70 to 85 mph across the Bristol Bay area and to around 75 mph in the Pribilof Islands. A very cold, post frontal airmass was in place across South Texas on December 4th through a sufficient depth of the atmosphere to produce wintery precipitation.  An upper level disturbance moved across South Texas generating initially rain during the early morning hours of the 4th.  The precipitation quickly changed over to snow across the Victoria Crossroads region and eventually mixed in with the rain all the way south to Corpus Christi.  The city of Victoria officially recorded 0.2 of snow, however 2-3 of snow was reported in rural parts of southeastern Victoria County. Sleet was also observed from Alice to Kingsville to Corpus Christi, however surface temperatures were too warm for any wintery precipitation to stick this far south. This was the the second earliest measurable snowfall of a winter in recorded history for Victoria.  The snow did force some school closures throghout the Victoria Crossroads region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: After a cloudy, cold afternoon on December 4th (temperatures in the lower 40s), skies rapidly cleared during the early evening as winds calmed, setting the stage for a widespread freeze overnight on the 4th into the morning of the 5th.  Temperatures fell to or below freezing before midnight in rural locations north and west of the urban Federal Highway 83 corridor, as well as in rural pockets along the border.  By daybreak, low temperatures ranged from the mid and upper 20s north of Edinburg to 30 to 32 in urban areas, including Weslaco, McAllen, and Pharr.  Aforementioned rural pockets near the Rio Grande fell to the mid 20s, as well.||Duration of the freeze across northern Hidalgo County, as well as rural pockets near the river, was measured and estimated to range from 7 to 10 hours.||In urban areas, away from known heat islands, 32 degree or lower temperatures lasted from 1 to 3 hours, except 3 to 5 hours in the urban/rural interface in such areas as Edinburg and Alton. ||The freeze was accompanied by several hours of frost, which combined with calm winds minimized notable damage to temperature sensitive crops.  Unprotected plants at individual residences may have received some damage, but costs were unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough of mid level low pressure, extending from the Upper Midwest southwest into Texas brought a period of cold rain and snow to South Texas on the 4th.  When the clouds cleared at the end of an unusually cold afternoon on the 4th, Canadian high pressure overspread the region overnight on the 4th and into the 5th, bringing the coldest surface temperatures in nearly 5 years to all of Deep South Texas. ||Morning lows on the 5th dropped to the mid 20s to around 30 in all counties, with freezing or lower temperatures lasting up to 6 hours in typically colder pockets.  The freeze was frosty for many critical agricultural areas of the Rio Grande Valley; temperatures hovering just below 32 combined with calm winds limited notable damage to protected crops and plants.
